slides.title: Hook: `is` vs `==` Confusion ü§Ø
slides.content: **`is` checks identity, `==` checks equality!** Sounds simple? But it can cause bugs that waste hours.

slides.title: What does `==` do?
slides.content:
```python
x = [1, 2, 3]
y = [1, 2, 3]
print(x == y)  # True: values are same
```

slides.title: What about `is`?
slides.content:
```python
x = [1, 2, 3]
y = [1, 2, 3]
print(x is y)  # False: different objects in memory
```

slides.title: When to use `is`? üßê
slides.content:
- Use `is` to check if two variables point to the **same object**
- Common with `None`: `if x is None:`
- Not for value comparison!

slides.title: Hook: 5 Data Types = 99% of Python Code üöÄ
slides.content: Master these 5, and you'll understand most Python programs! Ready to simplify?

slides.title: The 5 Data Types Explained
slides.content:
| Data Type | Description       | Example            |
| --------- | ----------------- | ------------------ |
| int       | Whole numbers     | `age = 25`         |
| float     | Decimal numbers   | `price = 9.99`     |
| str       | Text strings      | `name = 'Dhruv'`   |
| bool      | True or False     | `is_active = True` |
| list      | Collection of items| `nums = [1, 2, 3]` |

slides.title: Quick Code Peek üëÄ
slides.content:
```python
age = 25         # int
price = 9.99     # float
name = 'Dhruv'   # str
is_active = True # bool
nums = [1, 2, 3] # list
```

slides.title: Why These Matter? ü§î
slides.content:
- They cover numbers, text, truth values & collections.
- Knowing these helps you read & write Python FAST!
